body: did a bit more digging...jeez this bug has been around for almost 2 years..[this](http://bugs.python.org/issue12641) is getting a bit ridiculous

@cpcloud  Thanks for taking a look. I dug through SO myself and found a lot of posts on the issue, but I didn't find yours. After following the example in your first post I got rid of the original error:

``` shell
cc1.exe: error: unrecognized command line option '-mno-cygwin'
error: command 'gcc' failed with exit status 1 
```

And got a new one: 

``` shell
collect2: ld returned 1 exit status
error: command 'gcc' failed with exit status 1
```

The OP in first thread you posted seems to have sorted it out in Python 2.6 through a patch and additional steps. Unfortunately, there doesn't seem to be a patch for Python 2.7 so I cant follow the additional steps to solve the issue.  I'm still going to work on it but I thought this might be helpful information so far.

Has anyone else run into these issues when installing on windows? I don't want this thread to become a post on MinGW errors and irrelevant to Pandas but I think it might be helpful to link those posts to the docs in case anyone else runs into it.

Terminal output from install, with lots of undefiend reference erros:

@cpcloud  I've been meaning to get back to this. Installing and uninstalling the MinGW compiler did serious damage to my operating system's directory structure. I'll add more details later but the short version is that I had to completely re-install Windows. The experience pushed me to move from Windows to Linux. Now the dev version of Pandas works like a charm. I suggest that windows users who want to contribute / use the dev version spin up a Linux VM. If you guys agree its a better solution; I'd be happy to write a tutorial on it for the docs. Either way, thanks for help on the issue. Have a nice weekend!

**Summary:** Install Linux.

> The experience pushed me to move from Windows to Linux.

My evil plan is working! :smiling_imp:

In all seriousness, it's been my experience that anything involving compilation from source will be much easier on a UNIX based system. Of course, I'm unfamiliar with the dev toolchain on Windows and I would assume that it would be easier to compile things if I wasn't. That said, most of the devs around here are using Linux so it'll probably easier to get up and running with pandas dev if you have Linux going.

One solution is to create a Wiki page (maybe call it "Developing on Windows"?) detailing your experience (at whatever level of detail you want) and what you eventually decided to do. That way new users (using Windows) interested in contributing to pandas development can decide what they want to do in light of your experience, without alarming current Windows users and making them think that they need to switch to Linux. Sound okay?

http://bugs.python.org/issue3871
with patches for various python versions

I haven't tried it yet myself because my mingw gcc < 4.6
